verses.text: My child, do not rob the poor of their bread, and do not let the needy wait with longing.
verses.comment: Commences with a practical command resembling Proverbs; emphasizes care for the needy as an act of justice and mercy, foreshadowing the importance Christ places on caring for the poor (Matthew 25:35-40).

verses.text: Do not add to the sufferings of a broken heart, nor delay your giving to one in distress.
verses.comment: Touches upon active charity; neglecting someone in distress is a serious omission, reflecting Christ’s teaching on mercy (Luke 10:33-35: Good Samaritan).

verses.text: Do not reject the plea of an afflicted person, nor turn your face away from the poor.
verses.comment: The verse calls for responsiveness to those who suffer and points towards the biblical tradition of seeing the image of God in the poor and outcast.

verses.text: Do not overlook the tears of the oppressed, and do not be harsh with those in need.
verses.comment: Tears here symbolize deep suffering—an implicit call to compassion, echoing Christ’s empathy for the vulnerable.

verses.text: Do not let your heart be bitter toward those who are in want, and do not withhold your gift from the hungry.
verses.comment: Rooted in the tradition of almsgiving: a spiritual work of mercy and a practical act of righteousness.

verses.text: Reject not the request of the poor in their misfortune, and do not turn away your face from the needy.
verses.comment: Direct repetition for emphasis. In Jewish tradition, ‘turning away the face’ is a particularly strong rebuke; in light of Christ's commands to love neighbor, its gravity is increased.

verses.text: Do not avert your eyes from the poor, lest God avert his face from you.
verses.comment: Frames the encounter with the poor as sacramental: our relationship with God is mirrored by our treatment of others.

verses.text: Give freely to anyone who asks, and do not let anyone's misfortune turn you away.
verses.comment: Echoes Jesus in the Sermon on the Mount. Generosity and self-giving point toward the Christian call to imitate Christ’s own self-sacrifice.

verses.text: Let yourself be a father to the orphan, and like a husband to their mother; so shall you be like the Son of the Most High, and he will love you more than your own mother does.
verses.comment: A profound call to spiritual family and care, echoing God’s fatherhood and the church’s role as spiritual mother. The sonship language hints at adoption into God’s family through grace.

verses.text: Wisdom lifts up the humble, and she honors those who serve her.
verses.comment: Wisdom is personified in feminine terms—prefiguring the Logos, Jesus Christ, Wisdom incarnate (1 Corinthians 1:24).

verses.text: Those who love her love life; those who seek her early will be filled with joy.
verses.comment: Loving wisdom leads to true life—echoes the promise of abundant life offered by Christ in John 10:10.

verses.text: Those who hold her fast will inherit honor, and wherever the Lord goes, he will bless them.
verses.comment: Inheritance of honor links wisdom and divine blessing—spiritual rewards as well as temporal benefits.

verses.text: Those who serve Wisdom serve the Holy One, and those who love her are loved by the Lord.
verses.comment: Service to wisdom is service to God himself, reminiscent of Christ as the personified Wisdom (John 1:1-4).

verses.text: Those who listen to her will judge nations, and those who pay heed to her will dwell securely.
verses.comment: Wisdom is a source of true authority—reflects the promise that saints will reign with Christ (Rev. 20:4).

verses.text: If you entrust yourself to Wisdom, you will inherit her; the Lord will bless you.
verses.comment: Inheritance here is less material and more spiritual—life with God, the ultimate reward.

verses.text: But if you forsake Wisdom, you will not escape; those who betray her will fall into ruin.
verses.comment: Rejecting God’s wisdom brings calamity, consistent with warnings of spiritual consequences elsewhere in Scripture.

verses.text: She will walk with you in winding ways, and first bring fear and dread upon you and try you with her discipline, until she can trust your soul and test you by her laws.
verses.comment: Divine discipline is an act of love; spiritual training is needed before true wisdom is given, echoing the biblical principle of fatherly correction.

verses.text: Then she will come straight back to you, and gladden you, and will reveal her secrets to you.
verses.comment: After discipline, wisdom grants reward—God’s mysteries are revealed to the faithful. See Jesus' promise to the disciples about knowledge of the Kingdom (Matt. 13:11).

verses.text: But if you go astray, she will abandon you and deliver you to your own downfall.
verses.comment: There is justice in abandonment, reflecting the consequences of persistent disobedience.

verses.text: Watch for a favorable occasion, and do not neglect opportunities.
verses.comment: Vigilance and prudence are virtues, highlighted throughout the Wisdom literature.

verses.text: Do not be ashamed to confess your sins, and do not force the current of the river.
verses.comment: A call to open confession, echoing the biblical principle of forgiveness through repentance. Note the implication: openness brings healing, reflected in James 5:16.

verses.text: Do not submit to a foolish man, nor show partiality to a ruler.
verses.comment: Justice is impartial—echo of biblical teaching to respect all with fairness, regardless of status.

verses.text: Strive for truth, even to death, and the Lord God will fight for you.
verses.comment: Martyrdom and fidelity are honored. The Lord’s vindication of the righteous highlights the spiritual principle that dying for the truth is ultimate witness.

verses.text: Do not quarrel with someone, and do not trust them too quickly.
verses.comment: Cautions against imprudence and haste in judgment; to embrace peace and discernment.

verses.text: Do not be shy in speech when it may benefit you, and do not hide your wisdom.
verses.comment: Encourages assertive and charitable sharing of wisdom, fulfilling the call to teach and admonish one another in truth.

verses.text: For wisdom is known through speech; instruction through the tongue.
verses.comment: Vocal expression of wisdom leads others on the path of righteousness and spiritual growth.

verses.text: Do not contradict the truth, but feel shame for your ignorance.
verses.comment: Affirms humility and docility before truth—a spiritual disposition that opens one to God’s wisdom.

verses.text: Do not be ashamed to confess your sins, do not be stubborn against the stream.
verses.comment: Repeats earlier call for honest confession; spiritual healing comes through humility and repentance.

verses.text: Do not abase yourself before an unworthy man, and do not let others trample your dignity.
verses.comment: A reminder that true humility does not mean servility or self-loathing, but the proper recognition of your worth before God.

verses.text: Do not refuse to labor for justice, nor shrink from the work of rescue.
verses.comment: Justice and redemption are active tasks—an anticipatory sign of Christ’s own work of salvation.

verses.text: Do not say, 'I have enough,' or, 'What harm can come to me now?' In the time of adversity, remember that things can change; and at the moment of reward, remember poverty. From morning to evening things change; all things are soon gone before the Lord.
verses.comment: Teaches humility and dependence on God; prosperity and adversity are transient. Continually calls the believer to gratitude and humility, reminiscent of Jesus' teaching on storing up treasures in heaven (Matt. 6:19-21).
